In theory, versioning using media types sounds like a good idea, but  
in p=
ractice, it brings in some operational challenges.

a. Media type versionin=
g assumes that the same server instance  
supports all versions. But larger=
 systems may not be able to support  
multiple versions on the same runtime=
.

b. It further assumes versioning changes can be represented by  
represe=
ntations. In reality, versioning changes do bring in new  
resources and ne=
w processing flows.

c. The purported benefit of versioning by media types =
is that client- 
side databases don't need to be changed since the URIs are=
 the same.  
This is fine in small systems, but migrating a client from one=
 version  
to another version may require not just code changes, but databa=
se  
upgrades. This may be due to changes in the information content of  
r=
epresentations that the clients need to store,.

d. Not every HTTP level so=
ftware can distinguish between  
representation of a resource.

Given all t=
hese, even though URI based versioning looks inelegant, URI  
based version=
ing is more pragmatic, and is proven to work.

Subbu
